case_name: C. P. C. Motor Service, Mysore v. State of Mysore

facts.text: Civil Appeals No. 180 of 1961 filed by special leave from Mysore High Court judgment dated January 30, 1961 in Writ Petition No. 1326 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals No. 180 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 30, 1961, of the Mysore High Court, in Writ Petition No. 1326 of 1960.

facts.text: Appellants C. P. C. Motor Service, Mysore question scheme approved by State of Mysore via Notification No. HD. 200/TMP/60 in Gazette Extraordinary on November 10, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants, C. P. C. Motor Service, Mysore, question a scheme approved and applied by the State of Mysore by its Notification No. HD. 200/TMP/60 in Gazette  Extraordinary  on November 10, 1960.

facts.text: Appellants unsuccessfully moved Mysore High Court under Art. 226 of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: They had unsuccessfully moved the High Court under Art. 226 of Constitution, and the present appeal is filed with the special leave of this Court.

facts.text: Appellants were running stage carriage omnibuses on 18 routes, 14 inter-district.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were running stage carriage omnibuses on 18 routes, and 14 such routes are inter District.

facts.text: Second respondent, General Manager of State Transport Undertaking, published tentative scheme on September 21, 1960 for 64 routes to complete exclusion of private operators.

anchor.surface_text: On September 21, 1960, the second respondent, who is the General Manager of the State Transport Undertaking, published a tentative scheme for taking over stage carriage services over 64 routes, which were shown in a schedule to the Notification, to the companyplete exclusion of private operators.

facts.text: Action taken under Chap. IV-A of Motor Vehicles Act inserted by s. 62 of Act 100 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The action was taken under Chap. IV-A of the Motor Vehicles Act, inserted by s. 62 of Act 100 of 1956.

facts.text: Objections filed by appellants, heard by Chief Minister, disposed by order dated November 7, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Objections were duly filed by the appellants, which were heard by the Chief Minister, who was the authority to hear the objections under the Rules, and they were disposed of by his order dated November 7, 1960.

facts.text: Scheme approved with modifications, published with order in Notification on November 10, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme was approved with some modifications, and it was published along with the order in the Notification, to which we have already referred.

facts.text: Mysore High Court dismissed writ petition by judgment dated January 30, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, by its judgment under appeal dated January 30, 1961, dismissed the petition.

facts.text: High Court delivered common judgment on same day in Writ Petition No. 75 of 1960 concerning Hassan District scheme.

anchor.surface_text: Some of the grounds were companysidered in that judgment but others had already been disposed of in other petitions, in which a companymon judgment was delivered by the High Court also on the same day in Writ Petition No. 75 of 1960.

facts.text: Appellants challenge scheme on grounds: modified scheme vague indefinite contradictory, no compliance with ss. 68C and 68E, destructive of coordination, appellants' routes not affected.

anchor.surface_text: In the appeal before us, the scheme is challenged on four grounds. Shortly stated, they are, that the modified scheme is vague, indefinite and companytradictory and does number carry out the orders of the Chief Minister that has been number companypliance with the mandatory requirements of ss. 68C and 68E of the Motor Vehicles Act that the scheme is destructive of companyordination, which is the gist of efficient motor transport services and finally, that the routes on which the appellants operated, were, in any event, number affected by the monopoly on certain routes created in favour of the State Transport Undertaking.

facts.text: Private operators including appellants plied omnibuses on inter-district, intra-district and inter-state routes.

anchor.surface_text: Private operators in the Mysore State including the appellants, plied their omnibuses on three different kinds of routes. They were inter- District, inter-District and inter-State.

facts.text: State Transport Undertaking took over 64 routes, exclusion of private operators only in Mysore District.

anchor.surface_text: By the scheme, the State Transport Undertaking had taken over 64 routes, but the exclusion of the private operators was only in the Mysore District.

facts.text: Approved scheme states State Transport Undertaking operates to complete exclusion on all notified inter-district routes except portions outside Mysore District limits, and entire length within Mysore District.

anchor.surface_text: In the approved scheme, this is stated in the following words Whether the services are 1. The State Transport to be operated by the Undertaking will ope- State Transport Under- rate services to the taking to the exclusion, companyplete exclusion companyplete or partial, of of other persons i  other persons or other- on all the numberified wise. inter-district routes except in regard to the portions of inter- district routes lying outside the limits of Mysore District, and also  ii  over the en- tire length of each of the inter-district route lying within the limits of Mysore District.

facts.text: In scheme appendix, routes shown with stops, lengths, max vehicles and services by STU and private operators; private columns shown as Nil.

anchor.surface_text: In describing the routes in the appendix to the scheme, these routes were shown with all the stops between the termini, together with the length of the routes in miles, the maximum number of vehicles to be operated by the State Transport Undertaking and by private operators, and the maximum number of daily services  return trips  to be provided in relation to each route by the State Transport Undertaking and by the private operators.

facts.text: Chief Minister observed private operators contended exclusive operation on notified routes affects inter-district and inter-state routes, directed scheme modified.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Minister, in dealing with the objection of the private operators, had observed in his order as follows The Private Operators companytended that exclusive operation by the Mysore Government Road Transport Department on the proposed numberified routes might seriously affect them on certain Inter-District routes as well as Inter State routes.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds scheme not vague as particulars under s.68C provided, Nil for private operators result of takeover.

anchor.surface_text: The first question that has been raised is that the scheme is vague, indefinite and companytradictory. The vagueness, it is said, arises from the fact that though under s. 68C certain particulars have to be mentioned, they have number been so mentioned in the scheme.

facts.text: Fares and timings not included in scheme, left to State Transport Authority.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, the fares and the timings have been left out, and the State Transport Authority has been given the power to fix them.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds scheme not destructive of coordination due to partial nationalisation allowing transhipment at borders.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, the argument that the scheme is destructive of companyordination is number valid. No doubt, the private operators cannot run in the Mysore District, but can ply their omnibuses from the border of the Mysore District on routes, which were saved to them, and there is likelihood of transhipment from State-owned buses to private omnibuses at the border.

facts.text: Supreme Court interprets Chief Minister's order as intending exclusion only outside Mysore District for non-notified routes, no contradiction.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the error lies in number properly reading the order of the Chief Minister. In the sentence, It was companytended by the Objectors that if the Mysore Government Road Transport Department was to operate certain numberified routes to the companyplete exclusion of other operators, it would adversely affect the passenger transport system on certain portions of inter-State and inter-District routes which are number numberified, the words which are number numberified qualify number the word route but the word portions.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds inter-district routes of appellants affected as portions within Mysore District nationalised.

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that numberdistinction can be made between the numberification of a portion of the route of the private operators lying within the Mysore District and the numberification of a different route, in which the portion within the Mysore District is also included.

facts.text: No minimum number of trips/vehicles required in scheme per amended Rules.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it was companytended that the minimum number of trips and the minimum number of vehicles to be put on the road with respect to any route has number been indicated, and that this is number a proper scheme, because a scheme must show how companyparatively more efficient service is to be provided by the State Transport Undertaking.

holdings.text: The scheme is not vague, indefinite or contradictory because it complies with s. 68C by providing required particulars such as routes, stops, lengths, maximum vehicles and services; 'Nil' for private operators is the direct result of takeover; fares and timings are not required to be specified in the scheme and may be fixed by State Transport Authority.

anchor.surface_text: The first question that has been raised is that the scheme is vague, indefinite and contradictory. The vagueness, it is said, arises from the fact that though under s. 68C certain particulars have to be mentioned, they have not been so mentioned in the scheme. This point is illustrated by referring

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies s.68C textual requirements to scheme contents; rejects vagueness claim by explaining 'Nil' entries and omission of fares/timings as non-mandatory.

holdings.text: There has been compliance with mandatory requirements of ss. 68C and 68E as objections were heard and disposed by Chief Minister, scheme published with modifications, and required particulars provided.

anchor.surface_text: The first question that has been raised is that the scheme is vague, indefinite and contradictory. The vagueness, it is said, arises from the fact that though under s. 68C certain particulars have to be mentioned, they have number been so mentioned in the scheme.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reviews procedural steps under ss.68C/68E against facts; confirms publication, objections hearing, approval with mods.

holdings.text: The scheme is not destructive of coordination as partial nationalisation under s.68C permits transhipment at district borders between state and private buses.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, the argument that the scheme is destructive of coordination is not valid. No doubt, the private operators cannot run in the Mysore District, but can ply their omnibuses from the border of the Mysore District on routes, which were saved to them, and there is likelihood of transhipment from State-owned buses to private omnibuses at the border.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interprets s.68C to allow partial takeover; transhipment inherent in partial schemes does not imply lack of coordination.

holdings.text: There is no contradiction between Chief Minister's order and approved scheme; order read harmoniously provides for exclusive state operation on notified routes/portions within Mysore District, affecting non-notified inter-district routes pro tanto.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the error lies in not properly reading the order of the Chief Minister. In the sentence, It was contended by the Objectors that if the Mysore Government Road Transport Department was to operate certain notified routes to the complete exclusion of other operators, it would adversely affect the passenger transport system on certain portions of inter-State and inter-District routes which are not notified, the words which are not notified qualify not the word route but the word portions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies harmonious construction doctrine to resolve grammatical ambiguity in Chief Minister's order, aligning it with scheme.

holdings.text: Appellants' inter-district routes are affected by the scheme as it nationalises portions within Mysore District; no distinction between nationalising a route portion or a different overlapping route; permits curtailed pro tanto under s.68F(2)(c)(iii).

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that no distinction can be made between the nationalisation of a portion of the route of the private operators lying within the Mysore District and the nationalisation of a different route, in which the portion within the Mysore District is also included.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defines 'route' to include actual road portions; applies s.68F scheme effectuation; follows prior precedents on route meaning.

holdings.text: Scheme not defective for omitting minimum number of trips/vehicles as amended Rules no longer require it; complied with current Rules.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it was contended that the minimum number of trips and the minimum number of vehicles to be put on the road with respect to any route has not been indicated, and that this is not a proper scheme, because a scheme must show how comparatively more efficient service is to be provided by the State Transport Undertaking.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notes amendment to Rules removing minimum requirement; no challenge to Rules; thus scheme valid.

It is said that the ruling applies in the present case where what is numberified as for exclusive running by the State Transport Undertaking is number a definite portion of a route of a private operator but is a different route altogether.

anchor.surface_text: In the Motor Vehicles Act, the words used are route or area, and it has been held by this Court that these words mean the same thing Kondala Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation. The scheme of the Act in s. 68F 2  c  iii  also shows that the Regional Transport Authority, in giving effect to the approved scheme, may curtail the area or route companyered by the permit in so far as such permit relates to the numberified area or numberified route.

precedents.case_name: Kondala Rao v Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation
precedents.cited_proposition: route or area mean the same thing

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, the argument that the scheme is destructive of coordination is not valid. No doubt, the private operators cannot run in the Mysore District, but can ply their omnibuses from the border of the Mysore District on routes, which were saved to them, and there is likelihood of transhipment from State-owned buses to private omnibuses at the border.

The High Court, by its judgment under appeal dated January 30, 1961, dismissed the petition. Some of the grounds were considered in that judgment but others had already been disposed of in other petitions, in

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the error lies in not properly reading the order of the Chief Minister. In the sentence, It was contended by the Objectors that if the Mysore Government Road Transport Department was to operate certain notified routes to the complete exclusion of other operators, it would adversely affect the passenger transport system on certain portions of inter-State and inter-District routes which are not notified, the words which are not notified qualify not the word route but the word portions.

The High Court, by its judgment under appeal dated January 30, 1961, dismissed the petition. Some of the grounds were considered in that judgment but others had already been disposed of in other petitions, in
